title: How to Make Berry and Macadamia Nut Brownies

steps.headline: Preheat oven to 140°C fan forced or 160°C for non fan forced.
steps.description: Line a 20 x 30cm Lamington/slice pan with baking paper.

steps.headline: Melt butter gently over low heat and stir in cocoa.
steps.description: Stir until smooth and take off the heat.

steps.headline: Pulse the still frozen berries ina food processor to make berry "crumbs".
steps.description: You may puree them until smooth if desired, however this may make the brownies taste too sour. The goal is small chunks of berry flavour without sacrificing the taste of the berries or the chocolate.

steps.headline: Add sugar, berries, vanilla, yogurt and eggs (one at a time) to the cocoa butter.
steps.description: Stir well until combined. Add flour and nuts and stir again until just combined.

steps.headline: Spoon the batter into the lined tray and bake 30-35 minutes.
steps.description: You want the top to set but ideally not form a hard crust. Lower the temperature if you see it browning too quickly, or cover with baking parchment.

steps.headline: Allow to cool before slicing and serving.
steps.description: Cut the brownie "cake" in half at the middle, then into halves again to make 4 big slices, then cut these slices into 3 to make 12 portions. These freeze well, but if layering the slices ensure there is baking paper between layers or they may stick to each other.

text: Preheat oven to 140°C fan forced or 160°C for non fan forced. Line a 20 x 30cm Lamington/slice pan with baking paper. Melt butter gently over low heat and stir in cocoa. Stir until smooth and take off the heat. Pulse the still frozen berries ina food processor to make berry "crumbs". You may puree them until smooth if desired, however this may make the brownies taste too sour. The goal is small chunks of berry flavour without sacrificing the taste of the berries or the chocolate. Add sugar, berries, vanilla, yogurt and eggs (one at a time) to the cocoa butter. Stir well until combined. Add flour and nuts and stir again until just combined. Spoon the batter into the lined tray and bake 30-35 minutes. You want the top to set but ideally not form a hard crust. Lower the temperature if you see it browning too quickly, or cover with baking parchment. Allow to cool before slicing and serving. Cut the brownie "cake" in half at the middle, then into halves again to make 4 big slices, then cut these slices into 3 to make 12 portions. These freeze well, but if layering the slices ensure there is baking paper between layers or they may stick to each other. Finished!
